#Text=Argentinian workers preparing to defend control of factory
#Text=Tuesday , April 26 , 2005
#Text=Factory workers at a ceramic factory in Neuquén , Argentina are preparing to defend their autonomous running of their workplace , as the courts start to look at appointing an owner .
#Text=The workers have been running the factory themselves since the Argentinian government meltdown in 2001 , and say they are more effective working independently .
#Text=There are now 410 workers at FaSinPat ( ' Fabrica sin Patrones ' or ' Factory without Bosses ' ) , having hired over 170 new workers in four years of autonomous control .
#Text=The factory is widely known as Zanon , the name under the previous owner , Luis Zanon , who accumulated some US$ 170 million in debt , and shut down the factory , firing the workers .

#Text=Argentinian government and businesses were in chaos at the time , with the government dissolving repeatedly and defaulting on $ 88 billion of debt , inflation skyrocketing and people demanding money from banks who had closed their doors .

#Text=Like over 200 Argentinian workplaces facing similar conditions , the workers chose spontaneously to run the factory themselves , and continued maintenance and production , to keep trading on their own behalf .

#Text=Now thirty workers have travelled the 1,200 kilometers to Buenos Aires , presenting a petition containing thousands of signatures from all over the world at the central courthouse , and mobilising outside .
#Text=" With these actions we are marking a playing ground for the judge , " said Raul Godoy , Zanon worker and General Secretary of the Ceramists ' Union .
#Text=Reports of violence against a Zanon worker

#Text=As the government has continued its legal assault upon the Zanon factory , at least one factory employee has been reported to have suffered repeated threats and violence at the hand of unknown attackers .

#Text=Esteban Magnani , author of El Cambio Silencioso ( The Silent Change ) , a book about worker cooperatives in Argentina told UpsideDownWorld.org , " In Neuquen you have Jorge Sobisch , a right wing governor who wants to be the new [ President ] Carlos Menem ... wants to show how tough he is ...
#Text=" One of Kirchner ’s flags is human rights .

#Text=Now with this kidnapping and the continued threats , Kirchner should n’t have any excuse to not do something about this .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Subway workers , train workers , airline workers , other recuperated businesses and many other sectors have made it clear that the employees at Zanon will not be alone . "

column1: #Text=Says one Zanon worker , " We are willing to defend the factory with our lives . "
#Text=It may not come to that .
#Text=Governnor Sobisch has been attempting to evict the workers of Zanon in an ongoing , highly politicized legal battle for several years .
#Text=Sobisch has been ordered by the Federal Supreme Court of Argentina to evict the workers as soon as possible .
#Text=Other sources consulted about the past record of behavior by Sobisch do not reflect a record of overt violence against the workers .

#Text=At least one source from October 2004 said that Sobish wants the workers to leave the Zanon factory and work instead in a government-sponsored micro-enterprise project for unemployed workers , constructing prefabricated houses .
